displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of comments:

  • Overall sentiment: Predominantly negative. About 70% view the tariff policy as harmful to the U.S. economy, about 20% are supportive (often emphasizing long‑term benefits), and around 10% express mixed or minimal-impact views.
  • Main concerns among critics:
  • Higher consumer prices and inflation as businesses pass tariff costs on, reducing household purchasing power and overall spending.
  • Limited evidence of reshoring or job gains due to lost supply chains and investment uncertainty; some firms delay decisions or work around tariffs.
  • Harm to small businesses and uneven sectoral impacts, with perceived benefits accruing to a narrow group (e.g., investors timing markets).
  • Deteriorating trade relationships (especially with China), potential retaliation, and damage to the U.S.’s reputation as a reliable trading partner.
  • Risks of slower growth, reduced output/income, recession fears, and possible dollar weakness.
  • Arguments from supporters:
  • Protection for domestic industries and encouragement of “buy American” behavior.
  • Potential long‑term gains, including stronger bargaining power, stabilization, and increased federal revenue to aid the budget/deficit.
  • Mixed/uncertain views:
  • Some expect short‑term pain but long‑term gains; others see limited real impact due to corporate workarounds.
  • One perspective noted that while tariffs may raise revenue, projections also point to long‑run declines in GDP and wages, highlighting the trade‑offs.
  • Cross‑cutting theme: Distributional effects matter—several comments stress that consumers and small businesses bear most costs, while any benefits are concentrated, making the overall impact skew negative.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments

  • Sentiment balance: A strong majority view the tariff policy as negative for the U.S. economy and society, roughly three-quarters. Around one-fifth see potential or likely positives (often longer term), and a small share describe mixed or minimal effects or express uncertainty.

  • Main concerns (negative):

  • Higher prices and inflation: Many say tariffs act as a tax passed on to consumers, reducing purchasing power, raising grocery and everyday costs, and hurting lower- and middle-income households.
  • Small business strain: Frequent reports of higher input costs, delayed/canceled international shipments, and thinner margins; some cite reduced order volumes in logistics/shipping and customer hesitancy due to added duties.
  • Limited reshoring: Skepticism that jobs or factories will return quickly; supply chains are hard to rebuild and uncertainty discourages investment.
  • Retaliation and global relations: Fears of tit-for-tat tariffs, damaged relationships (especially with China and allies), and countries seeking to bypass U.S. trade.

  • Macroeconomic risk: Concerns about slower growth, reduced output, job losses, and recession risk; several note policy unpredictability increases business uncertainty.

  • Arguments in favor (positive/minority):

  • Protection and leverage: Tariffs seen as a way to protect domestic industries, encourage “Buy American,” level the playing field, and gain negotiating leverage.
  • Fiscal benefits: Some believe tariff revenue can support the budget and, after adjustment, contribute to broader economic strength.

  • Time horizon: Several concede short-term pain but expect long-term gains from reshoring, stronger industry, and fairer trade terms.

  • Mixed/conditional views:

  • Effectiveness depends on targeted, strategic application rather than broad, universal tariffs.
  • Some perceive companies finding workarounds, muting near-term impact.

  • A few note potential positives for certain sectors or investors even if broader consumer impacts are negative.

  • Lived experience vs. outlook:

  • Many cite firsthand effects—higher import duties, shipping delays, reduced package volumes, and pricier inputs—aligning with the negative view.
  • Supporters emphasize strategic goals, fairness, and prospective benefits that may materialize over a longer horizon.

In short, the prevailing view is that tariffs are raising costs for consumers and small businesses, heightening uncertainty, and risking global trade frictions, while a notable minority believe they can strengthen domestic industry and bargaining power, with benefits more likely over the long term.

[Question]

Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society?

answer.text_box: Eventually I believe companies will pass the tariff expense onto consumers that will raise prices on day to day items pricing out many consumers. It will ultimately hurt the economy.
